Title: Linking forum posts -compilers-01-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: Grinding my way through the assignments
Input.posts:
I think that most of what got me through the assignments is sheer stubbornness. I had to bash my head against the wall for a day or so on both semantics and codegen before making any progress at all. Fighting through the code hierarchy was really quite nasty; I really should have spent the time to learn code::blocks or some IDE before starting (instead I relied on old-school tricks like 'grep'). One 'Anonymous' mentioned spending 70 hours on each of the first 2 assignments; this is totally understandable. The assignments had several complicating factors, which interacted. In the last lecture, the prof mentioned how N features leads to $$N^2$$ interactions; these factors similarly slow things down. 1. Code in a weird hybrid of C++ and C, made back when C++ was just a kindergarten drawing. 2. Documentation in a bizarre yet incomplete mathematical notation (for example $$E(Id) = l_1$$ is basically $$l_1 := E(Id)$$, that is, we find $$l_1$$ by looking up $$Id$$ in the environment $$E$$. (Cool Reference manual page 26). Why are the starting assumptions listed at the *bottom*? Why not just read out the meaning of the mathematical shorthand and say, for example, To evaluate 'isvoid e0' [given E, S0, so] - evaluate e0, producing intermediate result r0 - if r0 is void (ie, 0, not a reference to some object ), result 'r1' := Bool(true), otherwise result 'r1' := Bool(false) - garbage collect r0 The result is r1. We assume that S0->S1->S2 is implied. To define '+' we need to add an attribute to the store; A store is a mapping S_n from locations l_i to values v_i, together with a list of unused locations U_n. Noting the store at each step is too cumbersome to bother with; it always changes. To evaluate 'e0 + e1': - evaluate e0, producing intermediate result r0 - store r0 in unused l0, SOMEHOW REMOVING l0 from U - evaluate e1, producing intermediate result r1 - store r1 in unused l1, SOMEHOW REMOVING l1 from U - create a new Int r2 in unused location l2 with value val(l0)+val(l1), and simultaneously discard r0, r1 (adding l0, l1 back to U, and removing l2 from U) - garbage collect r0, r1 The result is r2 in location l2. I'm still being fuzzy here, and failing to make the distinction between objects and references to objects; the base notation is ALSO fuzzy, but this fuzziness is concealed by the notation. Reading it out makes the flaws more obvious. BTW given the existence of side-effects, the concept of 'store' seems incomplete; it seems that a correct program might also, during the evaluation of e0, print 'F*** Y***' 10,000 times then clear the screen, as long as we move from store S0 to S1--I'm probably missing something here. It isn't like having more lines in a .pdf file costs anything. This class isn't a paper journal article. 3. Conflicting and/or unnecessary documentation. For example, the SPIM manual documents conventions for parameter passing (1st 4 parameters in $a0, $a1, $a2, $a3, return in $v0) that conflict with the ones assumed by the COOL support code. And the MIPS assembly language reference is excessive for our needs. 4. Red herrings. The lectures seemed to indicate that we could get by with just a stack machine in codegen, but 'let' and 'case' require that bindings from higher-up be available within their bodies, which means that some temporaries need to be frame-pointer relative, or that we need to keep track of relative locations within the stack. The result: $$Time_{total} = Time_{base} * Factor_{weird code base} * Factor_{math}$$ $$ * Factor_{Doc\>overflow} * Factor_{misconceptions} = LOTS$$ I'd estimate that $$Factor_{weird code base} = 2$$, $$Factor_{math}=1.2$$, $$Factor_{Doc\_overflow}=1.3$$, $$Factor_{misconceptions}=1.3$$. If the COOL support code were re-written and the documentation were cleaned up, these assignments could possibly be done in 1/4 the time. Conceptually, they were just not that difficult. I'll give a mildly negative review of this course; while there was significant value, I suspect I might have gotten greater $$\frac {value} {time\_ spent}$$ by taking other courses; I needed to drop 2 coursera courses down to 'audit' to have the time to do the assignments for this one.
Upvotes:
6
I agree with everything you wrote. Still, to keep things in perspective, we are given the opportunity to take an excellent course, in one of the best universities in the world, from anywhere in the world, for free. I am very grateful for that ...
Upvotes:
9
In short: great lectures and material, inconsistent and confusing documentation. I enjoyed struggling through the assignments but most of the things that Jason mentioned (especially the documentation and support code) threw me off while programming.
Upvotes:
3
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
The notation for the formal rules (type rules and execution rules) is borrowed from formal logic, with some added conventions that the programming languages people have added. Given that there is roughly 100 years of history behind that notation but it was only adopted for programming languages in the last 20 years, it is a bit jarring if you haven't seen it before. As to the questions about why these rules are written in a certain way, the answer is that that is how the logicians did it even before programming languages were invented---it certainly wasn't designed with programming languages in mind as a possible application.
Instructor's post : The notation for the formal rules (type rules and execution rules) is borrowed from formal logic, with some added conventions that the programming languages people have added. Given that there is roughly 100 years of history behind that notation but it was only adopted for programming languages in the last 20 years, it is a bit jarring if you haven't seen it before. As to the questions about why these rules are written in a certain way, the answer is that that is how the logicians did it even before programming languages were invented---it certainly wasn't designed with programming languages in mind as a possible application.

Input.threadtitle: Grinding my way through the assignments
Input.posts:
I think that most of what got me through the assignments is sheer stubbornness. I had to bash my head against the wall for a day or so on both semantics and codegen before making any progress at all. Fighting through the code hierarchy was really quite nasty; I really should have spent the time to learn code::blocks or some IDE before starting (instead I relied on old-school tricks like 'grep'). One 'Anonymous' mentioned spending 70 hours on each of the first 2 assignments; this is totally understandable. The assignments had several complicating factors, which interacted. In the last lecture, the prof mentioned how N features leads to $$N^2$$ interactions; these factors similarly slow things down. 1. Code in a weird hybrid of C++ and C, made back when C++ was just a kindergarten drawing. 2. Documentation in a bizarre yet incomplete mathematical notation (for example $$E(Id) = l_1$$ is basically $$l_1 := E(Id)$$, that is, we find $$l_1$$ by looking up $$Id$$ in the environment $$E$$. (Cool Reference manual page 26). Why are the starting assumptions listed at the *bottom*? Why not just read out the meaning of the mathematical shorthand and say, for example, To evaluate 'isvoid e0' [given E, S0, so] - evaluate e0, producing intermediate result r0 - if r0 is void (ie, 0, not a reference to some object ), result 'r1' := Bool(true), otherwise result 'r1' := Bool(false) - garbage collect r0 The result is r1. We assume that S0->S1->S2 is implied. To define '+' we need to add an attribute to the store; A store is a mapping S_n from locations l_i to values v_i, together with a list of unused locations U_n. Noting the store at each step is too cumbersome to bother with; it always changes. To evaluate 'e0 + e1': - evaluate e0, producing intermediate result r0 - store r0 in unused l0, SOMEHOW REMOVING l0 from U - evaluate e1, producing intermediate result r1 - store r1 in unused l1, SOMEHOW REMOVING l1 from U - create a new Int r2 in unused location l2 with value val(l0)+val(l1), and simultaneously discard r0, r1 (adding l0, l1 back to U, and removing l2 from U) - garbage collect r0, r1 The result is r2 in location l2. I'm still being fuzzy here, and failing to make the distinction between objects and references to objects; the base notation is ALSO fuzzy, but this fuzziness is concealed by the notation. Reading it out makes the flaws more obvious. BTW given the existence of side-effects, the concept of 'store' seems incomplete; it seems that a correct program might also, during the evaluation of e0, print 'F*** Y***' 10,000 times then clear the screen, as long as we move from store S0 to S1--I'm probably missing something here. It isn't like having more lines in a .pdf file costs anything. This class isn't a paper journal article. 3. Conflicting and/or unnecessary documentation. For example, the SPIM manual documents conventions for parameter passing (1st 4 parameters in $a0, $a1, $a2, $a3, return in $v0) that conflict with the ones assumed by the COOL support code. And the MIPS assembly language reference is excessive for our needs. 4. Red herrings. The lectures seemed to indicate that we could get by with just a stack machine in codegen, but 'let' and 'case' require that bindings from higher-up be available within their bodies, which means that some temporaries need to be frame-pointer relative, or that we need to keep track of relative locations within the stack. The result: $$Time_{total} = Time_{base} * Factor_{weird code base} * Factor_{math}$$ $$ * Factor_{Doc\>overflow} * Factor_{misconceptions} = LOTS$$ I'd estimate that $$Factor_{weird code base} = 2$$, $$Factor_{math}=1.2$$, $$Factor_{Doc\_overflow}=1.3$$, $$Factor_{misconceptions}=1.3$$. If the COOL support code were re-written and the documentation were cleaned up, these assignments could possibly be done in 1/4 the time. Conceptually, they were just not that difficult. I'll give a mildly negative review of this course; while there was significant value, I suspect I might have gotten greater $$\frac {value} {time\_ spent}$$ by taking other courses; I needed to drop 2 coursera courses down to 'audit' to have the time to do the assignments for this one.

I think that most of what got me through the assignments is sheer stubbornness. I had to bash my head against the wall for a day or so on both semantics and codegen before making any progress at all. Fighting through the code hierarchy was really quite nasty; I really should have spent the time to learn code::blocks or some IDE before starting (instead I relied on old-school tricks like 'grep'). One 'Anonymous' mentioned spending 70 hours on each of the first 2 assignments; this is totally understandable. The assignments had several complicating factors, which interacted. In the last lecture, the prof mentioned how N features leads to $$N^2$$ interactions; these factors similarly slow things down. 1. Code in a weird hybrid of C++ and C, made back when C++ was just a kindergarten drawing. 2. Documentation in a bizarre yet incomplete mathematical notation (for example $$E(Id) = l_1$$ is basically $$l_1 := E(Id)$$, that is, we find $$l_1$$ by looking up $$Id$$ in the environment $$E$$. (Cool Reference manual page 26). Why are the starting assumptions listed at the *bottom*? Why not just read out the meaning of the mathematical shorthand and say, for example, To evaluate 'isvoid e0' [given E, S0, so] - evaluate e0, producing intermediate result r0 - if r0 is void (ie, 0, not a reference to some object ), result 'r1' := Bool(true), otherwise result 'r1' := Bool(false) - garbage collect r0 The result is r1. We assume that S0->S1->S2 is implied. To define '+' we need to add an attribute to the store; A store is a mapping S_n from locations l_i to values v_i, together with a list of unused locations U_n. Noting the store at each step is too cumbersome to bother with; it always changes. To evaluate 'e0 + e1': - evaluate e0, producing intermediate result r0 - store r0 in unused l0, SOMEHOW REMOVING l0 from U - evaluate e1, producing intermediate result r1 - store r1 in unused l1, SOMEHOW REMOVING l1 from U - create a new Int r2 in unused location l2 with value val(l0)+val(l1), and simultaneously discard r0, r1 (adding l0, l1 back to U, and removing l2 from U) - garbage collect r0, r1 The result is r2 in location l2. I'm still being fuzzy here, and failing to make the distinction between objects and references to objects; the base notation is ALSO fuzzy, but this fuzziness is concealed by the notation. Reading it out makes the flaws more obvious. BTW given the existence of side-effects, the concept of 'store' seems incomplete; it seems that a correct program might also, during the evaluation of e0, print 'F*** Y***' 10,000 times then clear the screen, as long as we move from store S0 to S1--I'm probably missing something here. It isn't like having more lines in a .pdf file costs anything. This class isn't a paper journal article. 3. Conflicting and/or unnecessary documentation. For example, the SPIM manual documents conventions for parameter passing (1st 4 parameters in $a0, $a1, $a2, $a3, return in $v0) that conflict with the ones assumed by the COOL support code. And the MIPS assembly language reference is excessive for our needs. 4. Red herrings. The lectures seemed to indicate that we could get by with just a stack machine in codegen, but 'let' and 'case' require that bindings from higher-up be available within their bodies, which means that some temporaries need to be frame-pointer relative, or that we need to keep track of relative locations within the stack. The result: $$Time_{total} = Time_{base} * Factor_{weird code base} * Factor_{math}$$ $$ * Factor_{Doc\>overflow} * Factor_{misconceptions} = LOTS$$ I'd estimate that $$Factor_{weird code base} = 2$$, $$Factor_{math}=1.2$$, $$Factor_{Doc\_overflow}=1.3$$, $$Factor_{misconceptions}=1.3$$. If the COOL support code were re-written and the documentation were cleaned up, these assignments could possibly be done in 1/4 the time. Conceptually, they were just not that difficult. I'll give a mildly negative review of this course; while there was significant value, I suspect I might have gotten greater $$\frac {value} {time\_ spent}$$ by taking other courses; I needed to drop 2 coursera courses down to 'audit' to have the time to do the assignments for this one.
Upvotes:
6
I agree with everything you wrote. Still, to keep things in perspective, we are given the opportunity to take an excellent course, in one of the best universities in the world, from anywhere in the world, for free. I am very grateful for that ...
Upvotes:
9
In short: great lectures and material, inconsistent and confusing documentation. I enjoyed struggling through the assignments but most of the things that Jason mentioned (especially the documentation and support code) threw me off while programming.
Upvotes:
3
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
The notation for the formal rules (type rules and execution rules) is borrowed from formal logic, with some added conventions that the programming languages people have added. Given that there is roughly 100 years of history behind that notation but it was only adopted for programming languages in the last 20 years, it is a bit jarring if you haven't seen it before. As to the questions about why these rules are written in a certain way, the answer is that that is how the logicians did it even before programming languages were invented---it certainly wasn't designed with programming languages in mind as a possible application.
Instructor's post : The notation for the formal rules (type rules and execution rules) is borrowed from formal logic, with some added conventions that the programming languages people have added. Given that there is roughly 100 years of history behind that notation but it was only adopted for programming languages in the last 20 years, it is a bit jarring if you haven't seen it before. As to the questions about why these rules are written in a certain way, the answer is that that is how the logicians did it even before programming languages were invented---it certainly wasn't designed with programming languages in mind as a possible application.

Title: Linking forum posts -compilers-01-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: Grinding my way through the assignments

Input.threadtitle: Please release one of the programming/DeduceIt assignments a liitle early!
Input.posts:
In my experience, startup issues (installing tools, setting up the correct environment), and generally getting off the ground is usually the most time-taking (and sometimes frustrating) part of doing a programming project. It would be nice if you could release the first assignment a bit early so that people who have some free time could utilize it to get started. :) Alternatively, you could provide a link to the programming/DeduceIt assignments on one of the previous iterations of the course, so that if we have a headstart on the basic theory, we can get started a bit early. As of now, we can only preview the lectures.
Upvotes:
13
https://share.coursera.org/wiki/index.php/Compilers:PA2 might be interesting. My plan was to just take it easy this week, looking at the VM and testing out the various COOL examples. Maybe try to find my old flex and bison book, read the flex man page.
Upvotes:
0
DI is done online, so there is no setup issue, and if it was not improved you will get problems with later DI's because of some crazy syntax. As for PA2 and PA3 -- please write lexer+parser rules for text calculator: 'hello' gives you the text len('hello') gives you 5 len('hello\n') gives you 6, not 7 concat('h','e','y') gives you hey It is enough to make you set up your tools properly and understand how to generate lexer and parser before first assignment is given.
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
A couple of comments: If you are anxious to get going on the programming assignments you can go to the self-paced version of the class where all the lectures and assignments are available (caveat: it seems Cousera isn't really set up to have two instances of a class at the same time, so the self-paced version might not be readily accessible at this moment, but I hope it will be soon). The DeduceIt assignments need to wait a bit as there is some special setup that has to be done manually for a new instance of the class and that I'm not sure is complete yet.

A couple of comments: If you are anxious to get going on the programming assignments you can go to the self-paced version of the class where all the lectures and assignments are available (caveat: it seems Cousera isn't really set up to have two instances of a class at the same time, so the self-paced version might not be readily accessible at this moment, but I hope it will be soon). The DeduceIt assignments need to wait a bit as there is some special setup that has to be done manually for a new instance of the class and that I'm not sure is complete yet.
Instructor's post : A couple of comments: If you are anxious to get going on the programming assignments you can go to the self-paced version of the class where all the lectures and assignments are available (caveat: it seems Cousera isn't really set up to have two instances of a class at the same time, so the self-paced version might not be readily accessible at this moment, but I hope it will be soon). The DeduceIt assignments need to wait a bit as there is some special setup that has to be done manually for a new instance of the class and that I'm not sure is complete yet.
Upvotes:
2

Title: Linking forum posts -compilers-01-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
RequesterFeedback: Hi, if the instructor refers to posts collectively, please only mark the first post
Input.threadtitle: How much time are you spending on the programming assignments?
Input.posts:
Just wonder. I started the semantic analysis assignment and have already spent a few nights on it. I read ahead the code generation assignment is about twice amount the code I really wonder...
Upvotes:
2
I'm very interested in the amount of time you guys are spending on assignments 1 and 2. I started the course last week and that means I didn't have much time to spend on videos and notes, plus I did the quizzes 1 and 2 after the first deadline (obviously) so my grades suffered a lot. However I'm still on the game and I'm considering the effort of doing assignments to improve my chances - but I really can't afford much time to setup an environment and code. The only thing on my side is that I'm an experienced coder in both Java and C++. Does that make a big difference here?
Upvotes:
0
For the first two programming assignments, I probably spent about 10 to 12 hours on each. Unfortunately I have other obligations (like work) and have to work in stretches on the weekends. I have worked with C++, but had never really worked with Flex nor Bison, so I also spent probably about another 8 hours skimming the manuals and/or Googling for tutorials. (BTW, I would recommend the Lex & Yacc Tutorial by Tom Niemann which is about 40 pages and can easily be found on the Web.) I tend to think that the third and fourth programming assignment may require more C++ coding than the first two (which I found did not require much at all). I had to find time (late in the evenings or when I woke up early) to watch the videos. The notes are important to have (I downloaded them and had them open in another window) as some of the videos refer back to the notes after they were introduced. Most of the videos are reasonable in length and I usually found myself a week behind when working on the assignments. As far as setting up an environment and coding, there really is not too much that you need to do (at least for the first two assignments). Everything is already set up on the Virtual Machine for the course and if you read the assignment instructions carefully, the pattern is to create an assignment folder, acquire the setup scripts specified in the instructions and it pretty much sets everything up including make files. As a side-note, after working on the first two assignments, and going back to review the first couple of weeks' videos again things began to make more sense... in addition, it became a bit easier to read and understand the material in 'The Dragon Book' as the lectures help simplify some of the more complex concepts.
Upvotes:
7
Thanks for all the info, from reading that and other posts I decided to not try PAs with that goal, simply because I had no chance to meet the first due date - and it makes no sense to meet the dead hardline because the penalty would be so big, and I'd be already penalized for PA 1. I'll open another question to ask how the PAs helped people on the midterms
Upvotes:
0
I think it heavily depends on how much and what kind of programming experience you have; for example with reading and using someone else's code. I am quite familiar with the internals of C++, and roughly know how it translates to machine instructions. This greatly helps me in quickly understanding the lectures and how the constructs in Cool are supposed to work. In any case, decent programming experience is a huge plus. It also depends on your work style. a) I did not read the Flex or Bison manuals extensively, only for a few things that I did not know how to handle / couldn't figure out by just looking at the framework / starter code provided. If you start out by reading the manuals, I'm sure you will spend much more time (but perhaps may learn a bit more in the process). b) The grading scripts are great for making progress fast. You can work up a solution, run the script and see where it bugs (go into the grading folder to see the reference output and your output!). Actually, just looking at the reference output gives a ton of information on how to do the assignment. c) To get the final few points, you can either put a quick hack into your program, or rewrite it completely... For PA1 and PA2, I guess I spent about 6 hours (rough guess). PA3 is definitely more time consuming and took me about 12 hrs I think.
Upvotes:
1
I have spent several days intermittently thinking about each of the assignments trying to figure out how to get something going. Once I got the first bit of success, I still spent 8-10 hours banging against the grading examples and fixing it up. I am decent with C but not C++. I had not used the tools before and i found the environment tough going at first.
Upvotes:
6
To compare, I am somewhat familiar with flex and bison -- say 70% knowledgeable. I am very strong in C and moderately strong in C++; I can spell Java. I am also very familiar with Linux, so that learning curve didn't come into play for me. The first 2 programming assignments took about 8 and 6 hours for the lexer and parser respectively, including knocking out the grading scripts.
Upvotes:
1
The projects take way too long! (kidding, but only kind of.) Reading the materials just to start PA1 and PA2 took hours each. Once started, getting the lexer and parser to work with simple samples didn't take too long. Debugging far more complex test cases has taken 3-4 times longer. I didn't keep track, but I think those two assignments took around 10-12 hours each. The long time to complete each was due to the learning curve for me. I don't fear writing more code in the next assignment, but if it's learning to use yet another code generation tool I might scream. :) I wish that I had taken the Stanford Automata MOOC last year and had read a book on (f)lex and bison before taking this class. That way would have let me focus on the compilers part of this course instead of scrambling to pick up everything at once. edit: I checked out a copy of the O'Reilly Flex and Bison book and it's quite fantastic. 100 pages in and it covers pretty much everything you'd need for doing the first two assignments easier than using the provided resources links. And lol I didn't get accepted into Stanford when I applied years ago.
Upvotes:
2
Having the Automata course under my belt definitely made the lexing topics (regular languages, CFGs, DFAs & NFAs) a breeze. For me, the going got tougher from there--the midterm revealed that I really don't know a whole lot about SLR parsing. As for the PAs--I didn't get to the first one; may return to it for half credit. I'm struggling to get a toehold in the second so I can iterate against the grading script, but if I don't see some progress tomorrow morning, I'm breaking off and enjoying my Saturday. For the sheer bafflement factor of the PAs, this may be the winner. I was grinding through PGM this time last year, and the PAs were brutal, but at least it was possible to muddle through in 15 or 20 or 30 or more hours (each week for 9 weeks!). Here, I don't even know where to begin.
Upvotes:
0
I only remembered BNF as an acronym from a course I took many years ago; I had to constantly reference the bison and flex documentation myself. I found some good resources out on the Web that could distill it down a bit. (However, it seems like most examples I ran into only made a calculator!) Apparently finding a grammar for the 'life universe and everything' only turned up '42.y', and it only had a comment at the top which read: 'Don't Panic!' On another note, it certainly helped to do some searches on 'yacc grammar' or 'bison grammar' for some more of the popular languages. (i.e. bison grammar for ANSI C on Google.) Sometimes looking at how they handled certain language constructs (and I can assure you that Cool does some very non-conventional things) were good 'hints' at trying certain things. Don't feel bad, it took me longer than expected, but I really learned quite a few things in the process and I actually used my knowledge of regular expressions for something practical! Sometimes using the 'tools' to write other tools can save quite a bit of effort.
Upvotes:
2
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
I realize the programming assignments can be a lot of work. So people are aware of what is coming up, the third and fourth assignments are a lot bigger (as measured by the amount of code to be written) and more involved than the first two. I suppose the good news is that there are fewer new tools to learn---the main reason that you have to write more code is that there isn't a tool that automates a lot of the process in these assignments.
Instructor's post : I realize the programming assignments can be a lot of work. So people are aware of what is coming up, the third and fourth assignments are a lot bigger (as measured by the amount of code to be written) and more involved than the first two. I suppose the good news is that there are fewer new tools to learn---the main reason that you have to write more code is that there isn't a tool that automates a lot of the process in these assignments.

Actually, just looking at the reference output gives a ton of information on how to do the assignment. c) To get the final few points, you can either put a quick hack into your program, or rewrite it completely... For PA1 and PA2, I guess I spent about 6 hours (rough guess). PA3 is definitely more time consuming and took me about 12 hrs I think.
Upvotes:
1
I have spent several days intermittently thinking about each of the assignments trying to figure out how to get something going. Once I got the first bit of success, I still spent 8-10 hours banging against the grading examples and fixing it up. I am decent with C but not C++. I had not used the tools before and i found the environment tough going at first.
Upvotes:
6
To compare, I am somewhat familiar with flex and bison -- say 70% knowledgeable. I am very strong in C and moderately strong in C++; I can spell Java. I am also very familiar with Linux, so that learning curve didn't come into play for me. The first 2 programming assignments took about 8 and 6 hours for the lexer and parser respectively, including knocking out the grading scripts.
Upvotes:
1
The projects take way too long! (kidding, but only kind of.) Reading the materials just to start PA1 and PA2 took hours each. Once started, getting the lexer and parser to work with simple samples didn't take too long. Debugging far more complex test cases has taken 3-4 times longer. I didn't keep track, but I think those two assignments took around 10-12 hours each. The long time to complete each was due to the learning curve for me. I don't fear writing more code in the next assignment, but if it's learning to use yet another code generation tool I might scream. :) I wish that I had taken the Stanford Automata MOOC last year and had read a book on (f)lex and bison before taking this class. That way would have let me focus on the compilers part of this course instead of scrambling to pick up everything at once. edit: I checked out a copy of the O'Reilly Flex and Bison book and it's quite fantastic. 100 pages in and it covers pretty much everything you'd need for doing the first two assignments easier than using the provided resources links. And lol I didn't get accepted into Stanford when I applied years ago.
Upvotes:
2
Having the Automata course under my belt definitely made the lexing topics (regular languages, CFGs, DFAs & NFAs) a breeze. For me, the going got tougher from there--the midterm revealed that I really don't know a whole lot about SLR parsing. As for the PAs--I didn't get to the first one; may return to it for half credit. I'm struggling to get a toehold in the second so I can iterate against the grading script, but if I don't see some progress tomorrow morning, I'm breaking off and enjoying my Saturday. For the sheer bafflement factor of the PAs, this may be the winner. I was grinding through PGM this time last year, and the PAs were brutal, but at least it was possible to muddle through in 15 or 20 or 30 or more hours (each week for 9 weeks!). Here, I don't even know where to begin.
Upvotes:
0
I only remembered BNF as an acronym from a course I took many years ago; I had to constantly reference the bison and flex documentation myself. I found some good resources out on the Web that could distill it down a bit. (However, it seems like most examples I ran into only made a calculator!) Apparently finding a grammar for the 'life universe and everything' only turned up '42.y', and it only had a comment at the top which read: 'Don't Panic!' On another note, it certainly helped to do some searches on 'yacc grammar' or 'bison grammar' for some more of the popular languages. (i.e. bison grammar for ANSI C on Google.) Sometimes looking at how they handled certain language constructs (and I can assure you that Cool does some very non-conventional things) were good 'hints' at trying certain things. Don't feel bad, it took me longer than expected, but I really learned quite a few things in the process and I actually used my knowledge of regular expressions for something practical! Sometimes using the 'tools' to write other tools can save quite a bit of effort.
Upvotes:
2
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
I realize the programming assignments can be a lot of work. So people are aware of what is coming up, the third and fourth assignments are a lot bigger (as measured by the amount of code to be written) and more involved than the first two. I suppose the good news is that there are fewer new tools to learn---the main reason that you have to write more code is that there isn't a tool that automates a lot of the process in these assignments.

Title: Linking forum posts -compilers-01-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: How much time are you spending on the programming assignments?
Input.posts:
Just wonder. I started the semantic analysis assignment and have already spent a few nights on it. I read ahead the code generation assignment is about twice amount the code I really wonder...
Upvotes:
2
I'm very interested in the amount of time you guys are spending on assignments 1 and 2. I started the course last week and that means I didn't have much time to spend on videos and notes, plus I did the quizzes 1 and 2 after the first deadline (obviously) so my grades suffered a lot. However I'm still on the game and I'm considering the effort of doing assignments to improve my chances - but I really can't afford much time to setup an environment and code. The only thing on my side is that I'm an experienced coder in both Java and C++. Does that make a big difference here?
Upvotes:
0
For the first two programming assignments, I probably spent about 10 to 12 hours on each. Unfortunately I have other obligations (like work) and have to work in stretches on the weekends. I have worked with C++, but had never really worked with Flex nor Bison, so I also spent probably about another 8 hours skimming the manuals and/or Googling for tutorials. (BTW, I would recommend the Lex & Yacc Tutorial by Tom Niemann which is about 40 pages and can easily be found on the Web.) I tend to think that the third and fourth programming assignment may require more C++ coding than the first two (which I found did not require much at all). I had to find time (late in the evenings or when I woke up early) to watch the videos. The notes are important to have (I downloaded them and had them open in another window) as some of the videos refer back to the notes after they were introduced. Most of the videos are reasonable in length and I usually found myself a week behind when working on the assignments. As far as setting up an environment and coding, there really is not too much that you need to do (at least for the first two assignments). Everything is already set up on the Virtual Machine for the course and if you read the assignment instructions carefully, the pattern is to create an assignment folder, acquire the setup scripts specified in the instructions and it pretty much sets everything up including make files. As a side-note, after working on the first two assignments, and going back to review the first couple of weeks' videos again things began to make more sense... in addition, it became a bit easier to read and understand the material in 'The Dragon Book' as the lectures help simplify some of the more complex concepts.

Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
RequesterFeedback: Hi, if the instructor refers to posts collectively, please only mark the first post
Input.threadtitle: How much time are you spending on the programming assignments?
Input.posts:
Just wonder. I started the semantic analysis assignment and have already spent a few nights on it. I read ahead the code generation assignment is about twice amount the code I really wonder...
Upvotes:
2
I'm very interested in the amount of time you guys are spending on assignments 1 and 2. I started the course last week and that means I didn't have much time to spend on videos and notes, plus I did the quizzes 1 and 2 after the first deadline (obviously) so my grades suffered a lot. However I'm still on the game and I'm considering the effort of doing assignments to improve my chances - but I really can't afford much time to setup an environment and code. The only thing on my side is that I'm an experienced coder in both Java and C++. Does that make a big difference here?
Upvotes:
0
For the first two programming assignments, I probably spent about 10 to 12 hours on each. Unfortunately I have other obligations (like work) and have to work in stretches on the weekends. I have worked with C++, but had never really worked with Flex nor Bison, so I also spent probably about another 8 hours skimming the manuals and/or Googling for tutorials. (BTW, I would recommend the Lex & Yacc Tutorial by Tom Niemann which is about 40 pages and can easily be found on the Web.) I tend to think that the third and fourth programming assignment may require more C++ coding than the first two (which I found did not require much at all). I had to find time (late in the evenings or when I woke up early) to watch the videos. The notes are important to have (I downloaded them and had them open in another window) as some of the videos refer back to the notes after they were introduced. Most of the videos are reasonable in length and I usually found myself a week behind when working on the assignments. As far as setting up an environment and coding, there really is not too much that you need to do (at least for the first two assignments). Everything is already set up on the Virtual Machine for the course and if you read the assignment instructions carefully, the pattern is to create an assignment folder, acquire the setup scripts specified in the instructions and it pretty much sets everything up including make files. As a side-note, after working on the first two assignments, and going back to review the first couple of weeks' videos again things began to make more sense... in addition, it became a bit easier to read and understand the material in 'The Dragon Book' as the lectures help simplify some of the more complex concepts.
Upvotes:
7
Thanks for all the info, from reading that and other posts I decided to not try PAs with that goal, simply because I had no chance to meet the first due date - and it makes no sense to meet the dead hardline because the penalty would be so big, and I'd be already penalized for PA 1. I'll open another question to ask how the PAs helped people on the midterms
Upvotes:
0
I think it heavily depends on how much and what kind of programming experience you have; for example with reading and using someone else's code. I am quite familiar with the internals of C++, and roughly know how it translates to machine instructions. This greatly helps me in quickly understanding the lectures and how the constructs in Cool are supposed to work. In any case, decent programming experience is a huge plus. It also depends on your work style. a) I did not read the Flex or Bison manuals extensively, only for a few things that I did not know how to handle / couldn't figure out by just looking at the framework / starter code provided. If you start out by reading the manuals, I'm sure you will spend much more time (but perhaps may learn a bit more in the process). b) The grading scripts are great for making progress fast. You can work up a solution, run the script and see where it bugs (go into the grading folder to see the reference output and your output!). Actually, just looking at the reference output gives a ton of information on how to do the assignment. c) To get the final few points, you can either put a quick hack into your program, or rewrite it completely... For PA1 and PA2, I guess I spent about 6 hours (rough guess). PA3 is definitely more time consuming and took me about 12 hrs I think.
Upvotes:
1
I have spent several days intermittently thinking about each of the assignments trying to figure out how to get something going. Once I got the first bit of success, I still spent 8-10 hours banging against the grading examples and fixing it up. I am decent with C but not C++. I had not used the tools before and i found the environment tough going at first.
Upvotes:
6
To compare, I am somewhat familiar with flex and bison -- say 70% knowledgeable. I am very strong in C and moderately strong in C++; I can spell Java. I am also very familiar with Linux, so that learning curve didn't come into play for me. The first 2 programming assignments took about 8 and 6 hours for the lexer and parser respectively, including knocking out the grading scripts.
Upvotes:
1
The projects take way too long! (kidding, but only kind of.) Reading the materials just to start PA1 and PA2 took hours each. Once started, getting the lexer and parser to work with simple samples didn't take too long. Debugging far more complex test cases has taken 3-4 times longer. I didn't keep track, but I think those two assignments took around 10-12 hours each. The long time to complete each was due to the learning curve for me. I don't fear writing more code in the next assignment, but if it's learning to use yet another code generation tool I might scream. :) I wish that I had taken the Stanford Automata MOOC last year and had read a book on (f)lex and bison before taking this class. That way would have let me focus on the compilers part of this course instead of scrambling to pick up everything at once. edit: I checked out a copy of the O'Reilly Flex and Bison book and it's quite fantastic. 100 pages in and it covers pretty much everything you'd need for doing the first two assignments easier than using the provided resources links. And lol I didn't get accepted into Stanford when I applied years ago.
Upvotes:
2
Having the Automata course under my belt definitely made the lexing topics (regular languages, CFGs, DFAs & NFAs) a breeze. For me, the going got tougher from there--the midterm revealed that I really don't know a whole lot about SLR parsing. As for the PAs--I didn't get to the first one; may return to it for half credit. I'm struggling to get a toehold in the second so I can iterate against the grading script, but if I don't see some progress tomorrow morning, I'm breaking off and enjoying my Saturday. For the sheer bafflement factor of the PAs, this may be the winner. I was grinding through PGM this time last year, and the PAs were brutal, but at least it was possible to muddle through in 15 or 20 or 30 or more hours (each week for 9 weeks!). Here, I don't even know where to begin.
Upvotes:
0
I only remembered BNF as an acronym from a course I took many years ago; I had to constantly reference the bison and flex documentation myself. I found some good resources out on the Web that could distill it down a bit. (However, it seems like most examples I ran into only made a calculator!) Apparently finding a grammar for the 'life universe and everything' only turned up '42.y', and it only had a comment at the top which read: 'Don't Panic!' On another note, it certainly helped to do some searches on 'yacc grammar' or 'bison grammar' for some more of the popular languages. (i.e. bison grammar for ANSI C on Google.) Sometimes looking at how they handled certain language constructs (and I can assure you that Cool does some very non-conventional things) were good 'hints' at trying certain things. Don't feel bad, it took me longer than expected, but I really learned quite a few things in the process and I actually used my knowledge of regular expressions for something practical! Sometimes using the 'tools' to write other tools can save quite a bit of effort.
Upvotes:
2
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
I realize the programming assignments can be a lot of work. So people are aware of what is coming up, the third and fourth assignments are a lot bigger (as measured by the amount of code to be written) and more involved than the first two. I suppose the good news is that there are fewer new tools to learn---the main reason that you have to write more code is that there isn't a tool that automates a lot of the process in these assignments.

Input.threadtitle: How is AST generated from APS files?
Input.posts:
In the assignment PA it is written that Abstract Syntax Trees are generated from the APS files. What tool is used for that?
Upvotes:
1
Good question! I couldn't even find what APS stands for.
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
APS is a little domain-specific language for abstract syntax trees. Essentially you give it a description of what elements one wants in the abstract syntax tree and how they are related to each other and it generates all the code for constructors and traversals of the tree.
Instructor's post : APS is a little domain-specific language for abstract syntax trees. Essentially you give it a description of what elements one wants in the abstract syntax tree and how they are related to each other and it generates all the code for constructors and traversals of the tree.

Title: Linking forum posts -compilers-01-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: Third programming assignment ...
Input.posts:
Conceptually building a semantic analyser for Cool - the goal of this programming assignment is not too difficult Actually implementing the code in a limited amount of time and with relatively little guidance is quite daunting ... especially on a distance learning course In the spirit of being helpful (hopefully) I'm going to post various links that might be of help (at least as it seems to me) ... In connection with type checking I came across something called the Hindley Milner type checking algorithm ... There are some MIT lecture slides on it ... - PhD Thesis (heavy going) http://gergo.erdi.hu/projects/tandoori/Tandoori-Compositional-Typeclass.pdf MIT Lecture Slides ... very helpful (at least for me) ... http://web.mit.edu/6.827/www/old/lectures/L07-Hindley-Milner2Print.pdf and http://web.mit.edu/6.827/www/old/lectures/L06-Hindley-MilnerPrint.pdf There is an implementation in C++ at https://github.com/jaredhoberock/hindley_milner This implementation makes use of Boost variants .. (a topic I am relatively new too .. but I see what the gist of it is ... ) Some references on Boost variants that might be of help http://boost.cowic.de/rc/pdf/variant.pdf http://blog.wuwon.id.au/2012/08/an-inline-variant-visitor-for-c.html In connection with semantic analysis in C++ there were quite a few references to using the Visitor pattern e.g. http://www.cs.colostate.edu/~cs453/yr2012/Slides/12-AST-visitor.ppt.pdf http://www.arl.wustl.edu/~mlw2/cse431/lec/visitor.pdf http://www.swe.uni-linz.ac.at/research/deco/designPatterns/visitor/visitor.abstract.html [ in connection with this web page .. the link to the iterator pattern is broken .... but the notes and comments are very relevant .. ] The visitor pattern approach is (IMHO) quite an elegant one ... I'll see how I get along with trying it out ... Notes re. iterator pattern mentioned above (snippet) Visiting across class hierarchies. An iterator can visit the objects in a structure as it traverses them by calling their operations. But an iterator can't work across object structures with different types of elements. For example, the following Iterator interface can access only objects of type Item : template class Iterator { // ... Item CurrentItem() const; }; This implies that all elements the iterator can visit have a common parent class Item . Visitor does not have this restriction. It can visit objects that don't have a common parent class. You can add any type of object to a Visitor interface. For example, in class Visitor { public: // ... void VisitMyType(MyType*); void VisitYourType(YourType*); }; MyType and YourType do not have to be related through inheritance at all. To my mind this is all pretty heavy going C++ coding .. and requires investing a lot of time in mastering quite a lot of more advanced C++ topics ... e.g Boost, templates, STL ... A small contribution, but still its a start (I hope) ... As I crawl along the stony path to possible enlightenment I'll try and contribute the various breadcrumbs that have served as markers on the way ... It would be nice if fellow pilgrims and strugglers could also add their breadcrumbs of partial enlightenment ...
Upvotes:
4
Now on to acyclic graphs … Useful links … Cornell lecture on graph traversals .. that I found helpful … http://www.cs.cornell.edu/courses/CS2112/2012sp/lectures/lec24/lec24-12sp.html It seems that the two strategies to consider are topological sorting and depth first search … These are various links and examples that I felt might be of use … http://architects.dzone.com/articles/algorithm-week-topological-0 Topological sort and hashing www.cs.sjsu.edu/faculty/lee/cs146/PhillipNTruong.ppt Shortest paths and topological sorting https://www.ics.uci.edu/~eppstein/161/960208.html Graph algorithms – general - http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~avrim/451f11/lectures/lect1011.pdf Dynamic topologica sort for directed acyclic graphs https://www.doc.ic.ac.uk/~phjk/Publications/DynamicTopoSortAlg-JEA-07.pdf topological sorting http://kartikkukreja.wordpress.com/2013/06/26/topological-sorting/ and a C++ code snippet http://www.geeksforgeeks.org/topological-sorting/ - a useful starter .. Syntax directed translation … quite useful .. including the final programming assignment (I think) http://www.computing.dcu.ie/~hamilton/teaching/CA448/notes/semantic.pdf and also .. from a Columbia university course … http://www1.cs.columbia.edu/~aho/cs4115/lectures/14-03-24.htm Well .. that's something to be getting along with …

Hi Andrew, I responded to Bill in another thread regarding my use of the 'Visitor' pattern (that you had mentioned above) which I think works *very* nicely without having to continually add to the interface or constructor implementation classes through the use of the #define macros in cool-tree.handcode.h. In addition, it makes it very easy to traverse the members of the AST and separate the concerns of each type of visitor into different classes of specific functionality. (For example, I have one visitor which creates they symbol tables, one for dumping diagnostic information and a separate visitor for semantic rules.) You can find my reply in the other thread here: https://class.coursera.org/compilers-004/forum/thread?thread_id=609 Let me know if you have any questions, the pattern is fairly simple to implement, but the 'double dispatch' in how it works takes a few minutes to grok. You can think of this pattern as a way to add specialized 'virtual' methods to many different classes without continually making changes to those classes to support that specialized functionality. Regards, Joe

Now .. on to symbol tables Implementing a symbol table in C++ Basics : http://www.d.umn.edu/~rmaclin/cs5641/Notes/L15_SymbolTable.pdf Starter discusions and lectures http://stackoverflow.com/questions/6184539/building-symbol-table-using-hash-table http://www.ida.liu.se/~TDDB44/lessons/ccl2.pdf http://www.ida.liu.se/~TDDB44/lessons/ccl2.pdf – good lecture on symbol tables and static checks … Suggestion from http://cobweb.cs.uga.edu/~kochut/Teaching/x570/symtab/symtab.html My suggestion is to implement the symbol table as an array (or alternatively as a vector ) of map's . The following two small programs illustrate the use of the two types: vector.cpp and map.cpp . Vector.cpp code snippet … [just to review the syntax] #include #include #include using namespace std; int main() { vector v; vector v1; int i; // insert string at the end // v.push_back( 'hi' ); v.push_back( 'there' ); v.push_back( 'you' ); v.push_back( 'guys!' ); // insert int's at the beginning // for( i = 0; i < 10; i++ ) v1.insert( v1.begin(), i ); // list all strings in v // for( i = 0; i < v.size(); i++ ) cout << v[i] << ' '; cout << endl; // list all int's in v1 // for( i = 0; i < v1.size(); i++ ) cout << v1[i] << ' '; cout << endl; } map.cpp code snippet … just to review the syntax #include #include #include using namespace std; struct less_string { bool operator()(string s1, string s2) const { return s1.compare(s2) < 0; } }; struct less_int { bool operator()(int i1, int i2) const { return i1 < i2; } }; int main() { map dig2num; map num2dig; int val; dig2num['zero'] = 0; dig2num['one'] = 1; dig2num['two'] = 2; dig2num['three'] = 3; dig2num['four'] = 4; dig2num['five'] = 5; dig2num['six'] = 6; dig2num['seven'] = 7; dig2num['eight'] = 8; dig2num['nine'] = 9; num2dig[0] = 'zero'; num2dig[1] = 'one'; num2dig[2] = 'two'; num2dig[3] = 'three'; num2dig[4] = 'four'; num2dig[5] = 'five'; num2dig[6] = 'six'; num2dig[7] = 'seven'; num2dig[8] = 'eight'; num2dig[9] = 'nine'; cout << '5 = ' << num2dig[5] << endl; cout << 'five = ' << dig2num['five'] << endl; val = dig2num['five']; map::iterator cur = num2dig.find(val); map::iterator prev = cur; map::iterator next = cur; ++next; --prev; cout << 'Before 'five' is '' << num2dig[(*prev).first] << ''\n'; cout << 'After 'five' is '' << num2dig[(*next).first] << ''\n'; } From Gamedev … http://www.gamedev.net/topic/579253-symbol-table-implementation/ … some advice … Data structures for symbol tables: 1. map May be fast enough for all practical purposes. For large symbol tables, it should not be used, because one lookup requires O(log n) comparison operations, and string comparison is expensive. 2. Hash maps (boost::unordered_map, std::unordered_map, etc.) Should be fine in most cases, and implementations are readily available 3. Ternary trees http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ternary_search_tree If it really has to be something fancy. I think, boost::spirit has or had a utility library which uses ternary trees. Since I mentioned it, one word of warning about boost::spirit: Although it is tempting to use a pure C++ source code only library as your parser, this library can be a major pain in the ass. Either you are prepared for tons of cryptic compiler errors, compiler crashes, loooooooong compilation times and learning more about C++, Boost and functional programming than you ever wanted to, or you better stay away from it. From http://www.cs.vassar.edu/~cs331/symbol_table/symtabclass.html Symbol table class JAVA Programmers Java includes a Hashtable class which makes setting up the symbol table class trivial. You will need to implement a dump table method (see below). C++ programmers This is what you need to implement for the symbol table calss: Class data member table_size Class behavior Constructor Insert in symbol table Look up in symbol table Dump table contents Destructor Class relationships Uses classes derived from Symbol_table_entry class Constructor Allocates a hash table of size table_size Initializes all entries in the hash table to null Destructor Deletes entire table and contents Dump table contents Shows all entries currently in the hash table and their locations, in terms of (1) the hash table cell and (2) position on the linked list. Use the entry's print function (defined for each type of symbol table entry--see Symbol table entry class ) to print the entry contents. Example output for 3 names occupying two cells of the hash table (e.g., 'a' and 'bbx' both hashed to location 2; 'bbx' was inserted before 'a'): Cell Entries 2 name: a name: bbx 4 name: fred Gives statistics indicating tablesize number of non-empty cells average number of entries per cell. Hash functions You are free to use these, but if you do you must explain how they work in a comment at the head of the function definition. http://www.cs.vassar.edu/~cs331/symbol_table/symbtabentrycls.html Symbol Table Entries Symbol_table_entry class is a base class. Several different subclasses of symbol table entries will be derived from this class, each designed to store and provide attribute information for the various identifiers that are encountered in the source program. Symbol table entry base class Public members: virtual string get_name() {return name;} virtual TypeInfo get_type() {return 0;} virtual int is_variable() {return 0;} virtual int is_keyword() {return 0;} virtual int is_proc() {return 0;} virtual int is_function() {return 0;} virtual int is_function_result() {return 0;} virtual int is_parameter() {return 0;} virtual int is_array() {return 0;} virtual void print (); Protected members: Symbol_table_entry () {;} Symbol_table_entry (string Name) {name = Name;} string name; Notes The only piece of data common to all symbol table entries is the character string containing the string's identifier. TypeInfo is an enumerated type with two values: integer and real. Protected members are available only to classes derived from the base class. The actual implementation of the data member name is protected, so a special member function get_name() is publically provided. Virtual function members of the base class are provided so that we can invoke the corresponding functions for specific objects. The print function in particular will differ for each type of entry. Derived classes You need classes for the following entry types. The required fields are indicated for each. Keyword_entry name Constant_entry name, type Variable_entry name, type, address Procedure_entry name, number of parameters, pointer to parameter information Function_entry name, type, number of parameters, pointer to parameter information, pointer to result variable (a Variable_entry) Array_entry name, type, upper bound, lower bound, address Function_result_entry name, type, address Note that function result variables are just simple variables (i.e., they have the same fields), except that the method is_function_result is defined differently. Here is one example of an implementation for the derived classes for Variable_entry class. Note that the virtual functions is_variable and print are redefined. Note also that a value is passed to the constructor to set the return value of is_parameter appropriately; since it defaults to 0, this value can be omitted when instantiating a variable entry that is not a parameter. You will have to do the same thing for array entries, which can also be parameters. Public members: Variable_entry() {;} Variable_entry(string Name, TypeInfo Type, int p=0); /* inside this constructor set parm = p */ int is_variable() {return 1;}; int is_parameter() {return parm;}; void print(); Private members: TypeInfo type; int address; int parm; Lecture on symbol table implementation – pretty good one too … implementations www.csie.ntnu.edu.tw/~ghhwang/course_slices/compiler/Chapter8.ppt From Princeton .. implementing a symbol table in C assignment … sometimes starting with C (I find … ) helps when thinking about the C++ http://www.cs.princeton.edu/courses/archive/fall07/cos217/asgts/symtable/ University of Linz lecture on Symbol tables http://www.ssw.uni-linz.ac.at/Misc/CC/slides/05.SymbolTable.pdf Binary tree approach to symbol tables in C http://www.seas.upenn.edu/~cit593/cit593f09/tutorials/tut9/symboltable.html Concise .. Slideshare presentation .. http://www.slideshare.net/Tech_MX/symbol-table-design-compiler-construction

Getting more control over the third programming assignment : I have not got the time to sort out all the various bits and pieces and put them into a reasonably useful IDE such as Eclipse CDT or NetBeans for C++ projects (same can be said regarding Java). Doing so would make life so much easier … Maybe the next incarnation of the course could come with support for either Eclipse or NetBeans that would make debugging, digging around and getting to various definitions etc. so much easier … As it is we have to stick to the “gnarly old ways” of vi or emacs and makefiles … Yes .. and stirling use of grep and find and such good things … The Makefiles are moderately tricky and it would be nice if they were thoroughly documented … Here is the Makefile in all its glory ASSN = 4 CLASS= cs143 CLASSDIR= /usr/class/cs143/cool LIB= -lfl AR= gar ARCHIVE_NEW= -cr RANLIB= gar -qs SRC= semant.cc semant.h cool-tree.h cool-tree.handcode.h good.cl bad.cl README CSRC= semant-phase.cc symtab_example.cc handle_flags.cc ast-lex.cc ast-parse.cc utilities.cc stringtab.cc dumptype.cc tree.cc cool-tree.cc TSRC= mycoolc mysemant cool-tree.aps CGEN= HGEN= LIBS= lexer parser cgen CFIL= semant.cc ${CSRC} ${CGEN} LSRC= Makefile OBJS= ${CFIL:.cc=.o} OUTPUT= good.output bad.output CPPINCLUDE= -I. -I${CLASSDIR}/include/PA${ASSN} -I${CLASSDIR}/src/PA${ASSN} FFLAGS = -d8 -ocool-lex.cc BFLAGS = -d -v -y -b cool --debug -p cool_yy ASTBFLAGS = -d -v -y -b ast --debug -p ast_yy CC=g++ CFLAGS=-g -Wall -Wno-unused -Wno-write-strings ${CPPINCLUDE} -DDEBUG FLEX=flex ${FFLAGS} BISON= bison ${BFLAGS} DEPEND = ${CC} -MM ${CPPINCLUDE} source: ${SRC} ${TSRC} ${LIBS} lsource lsource: ${LSRC} ${OUTPUT}: semant @rm -f ${OUTPUT} ./mysemant good.cl >good.output 2>&1 -./mysemant bad.cl >bad.output 2>&1 compile: semant change-prot change-prot: @-chmod 660 ${SRC} ${OUTPUT} SEMANT_OBJS := ${filter-out symtab_example.o,${OBJS}} semant: ${SEMANT_OBJS} lexer parser cgen ${CC} ${CFLAGS} ${SEMANT_OBJS} ${LIB} -o semant symtab_example: symtab_example.cc ${CC} ${CFLAGS} symtab_example.cc ${LIB} -o symtab_example .cc.o: ${CC} ${CFLAGS} -c $< dotest: semant good.cl bad.cl @echo '\nRunning semantic checker on good.cl\n' -./mysemant good.cl @echo '\nRunning semantic checker on bad.cl\n' -./mysemant bad.cl ${LIBS}: ${CLASSDIR}/etc/link-object ${ASSN} $@ # These dependencies allow you to get the starting files for # the assignment. They will not overwrite a file you already have. ${SRC} : -${CLASSDIR}/etc/copy-skel ${ASSN} ${SRC} ${LSRC} : -${CLASSDIR}/etc/link-shared ${ASSN} ${LSRC} ${TSRC} ${CSRC}: -ln -s ${CLASSDIR}/src/PA${ASSN}/$@ $@ ${HSRC}: -ln -s ${CLASSDIR}/include/PA${ASSN}/$@ $@ submit-clean: ${OUTPUT} -rm -f *.s core ${OBJS} ${CGEN} ${HGEN} lexer *~ parser cgen semant symtab_example clean : -rm -f ${OUTPUT} *.s core ${OBJS} semant cgen symtab_example parser lexer *~ *.a *.o clean-compile: @-rm -f core ${OBJS} ${LSRC} %.d: %.cc ${SRC} ${SHELL} -ec '${DEPEND} $< | sed '\''s/\($*\.o\)[ :]*/\1 $@ : /g'\'' > $@' -include ${CFIL:.cc=.d} Now lets start focusing : semant is obtained by linking together the object files associated with the variable SEMANT_OBJS, On further inspection we can see the this involves filtering out the object file symtab_example.o from the objects files associated with the variable OBJS This, in turn is formed by the combination of files associated with the variables CSRC and CGEN CGEN has no files and this leaves us with semant-phase.cc handle_flags.cc ast-lex.cc ast-parse.cc stringtab.cc utilities.cc dumptype.cc tree.cc cool-tree.cc Some of these files we leave alone ... and some we modify ... The output of the parser is fed into semant (the semantic analyser) So, where is main() ? answer in semant-phase.cc what does main do well it calls handle_flags(argc, argv) .. don't need to worry about that for now ast_yyparse() … which is a #define for yyparse() … so that's OK and yyparse() builds the parse tree with the global variable ast_root pointing to the root of the parse tree … it then calls the semant() method and then finally the dump_with_types() method So, I guess the first sensible thing to do would be to write little bits of code for traversing the parse tree in all sorts of ways … The nodes of the parse tree are objects derived from a common base class – Object .. Now, traditionally a tree node will have some kind of pointer or reference to a collection of child nodes … and so on down to the leaves at the bottom of the tree … But … how are the tree nodes structured here ? And what methods are available (if any) for iterating over the child tree nodes or going up to the parent node ? Even worse … what if there are loops in the tree (in which case, of course it is a graph and not a tree). In principle it does not have to be a strict tree … as a directed acyclic graph is a graph with no cycles … This means that a naïve tree traversal might not necessarily do the job [unless I have missed something vital … ] So, I suppose it might be nice to have some code that can decide whether what he have is a classical tree a directed acyclic graph (where the direction is from parent to child) a directed graph with cycles (in which case we have an error .. so moan away to output !!) It would be nice if the course materials provided some UML class diagrams … I suppose it might be interesting to throw the code into something like Enterprise Architect and see what it “spat out” … As a COOL program is made up of a collection of classes and these classes may have all kinds of inheritance relationships we are also asked to work out the inheritance hierarchy and this inheritance hierarchy must have no cycles … Question for later … I can't recall all the details of COOL syntax … does COOL support multiple inheritance .. (nasty diamond of death scenarios … ugh !!) So .. a mini sub-project would be to work out how to construct a class inheritance graph / tree and check that it has no cycles … Well .. I suppose its time to start writing little snippets of code [which we must all do individually … ] … however I presume that discussing alternative patterns and strategies and discussing insights into the various classes / utilities provided is permissible ???

Exploring the various classes for the various language objects : Starting at the top … what clues are there … Looking in cool-tree.h.SKEL class program_class : public Program_class { protected: Classes classes; public: program_class(Classes a1) { classes = a1; } Program copy_Program(); void dump(ostream& stream, int n); etc … }; So .. an instance of a program_class has a collection of Classes and we know that typedef Classes_class *Classes; … so here Classes is a pointer to a Classes_class and furthermore typedef list_node Classes_class; Classes_class is a templated list_node Now all we have in the assignments directory when we do something like grep -r 'Classes_class' assignments is a whole lot of typedef list_node XXXX_class; hits However .. searching further we get - after grepping over the entire cool directory grep -r 'list_node' * src/PA4/dumptype.cc:// AST are built using the class list_node defined in tree.h. The relevant snippet in tree.h seems to be template class list_node : public tree_node { public: tree_node *copy() { return copy_list(); } Elem nth(int n); // The next three define a simple iterator. int first() { return 0; } int next(int n) { return n + 1; } int more(int n) { return (n < len()); } virtual list_node *copy_list() = 0; virtual ~list_node() { } virtual int len() = 0; virtual Elem nth_length(int n, int &len) = 0; static list_node *nil(); static list_node *single(Elem); static list_node *append(list_node *l1,list_node *l2); }; Which looks pretty standard .. So .. the big enlightenment .. program_class is derived from Program_Class and provides a handle to a collection of classes … However … the list_node is a pure virtual base class … it does have a virtual destructor (as it should) and pure virtual methods which must be supplied in a suitable derived class , namely - copy_list() , len() and nth_length() it also has several static methods that return a list_node pointer namely - nil(), single() and append() So I suppose that the next thing to do is to work out the classes that should be derived from list_node Searching deeper we find … : template class nil_node : public list_node template class single_list_node : public list_node template class append_node : public list_node … and now we can start to get an idea of what is going on … … wow … this is moderately heavy C++ going … So … how do we know whether we have a nil_node or a single_list_node or an append_node ? … presumably the len() method provides the necessary clue ???

Some useful snippets and associated insights … In the Forum … Getting started on 3rd Assignment Bill Rowe did the kind of thing I was also planning to do as part of the getting my head around all the various bits and pieces provided .. namely to explore the behaviour of the reference semantic parser … I snip in the relevant part here … I always struggle at the beginning of these things but i am beginning to develop a clue and i thought i would share. After creating a directory and retrieving the files, I decided to see what the reference semantic checker does. I created an input file for it by running the reference lexer and parser on the hello_world.cl example: ./lexer /usr/class/cs143/examples/hello_world.cl | ./parser >hello_world.sin The output is shown below: #1 _program #1 _class Main IO '/usr/class/cs143/examples/hello_world.cl' ( #1 _method main SELF_TYPE #1 _dispatch #1 _object self : _no_type out_string ( #1 _string 'Hello, World.\n' : _no_type ) : _no_type ) I then ran the reference semantic checker on that .sin file with 'refsemant ' mean in 'ast_root->semant(); and Joseph Delekto helped out with … st_root is a pointer to a class object. When you call C++ methods through a pointer, you need to use '->' instead of just a dot '.' Further on in the forum … a very useful contribution (also from Joseph) …. The dump() method is a virtual method of the tree_node class. The 'phylum' classes (refer to cool-tour.pdf) derive from tree_node which has a pure virtual dump() method that must be overridden in the derived classes. These overrides, in turn, can call dump() on any of their members within the tree, etc. I recommend actually stepping through the code and into the overrides so that you can see how all these calls are being made. If you are not comfortable with using GDB from the command line, and would like to debug with an IDE, I recommend Code::Blocks which you can install in the Virtual Machine provided for this course. It will allow you to do single-step (over and into) debugging through the source code. Which inspired Bill … I realized that the code I wanted was actually dump_with_types which is defined in dumptype.cc and has an explicit iterator and some good pointers. Now … how does dump_with_types get into the code … This is where the cool_tree.handcode.h comes into the picture … …. a whole lot of sneaky #defines that explain what the various #ifdefs in the various type classes are doing … snippet follows : #define Program_EXTRAS \ virtual void semant() = 0; \ virtual void dump_with_types(ostream&, int) = 0; #define program_EXTRAS \ void semant(); \ void dump_with_types(ostream&, int); #define Class__EXTRAS \ virtual Symbol get_filename() = 0; \ virtual void dump_with_types(ostream&,int) = 0; #define class__EXTRAS \ Symbol get_filename() { return filename; } \ void dump_with_types(ostream&,int); #define Feature_EXTRAS \ virtual void dump_with_types(ostream&,int) = 0; #define Feature_SHARED_EXTRAS \ void dump_with_types(ostream&,int); #define Formal_EXTRAS \ virtual void dump_with_types(ostream&,int) = 0; #define formal_EXTRAS \ void dump_with_types(ostream&,int); #define Case_EXTRAS \ virtual void dump_with_types(ostream& ,int) = 0; #define branch_EXTRAS \ void dump_with_types(ostream& ,int); #define Expression_EXTRAS \ Symbol type; \ Symbol get_type() { return type; } \ Expression set_type(Symbol s) { type = s; return this; } \ virtual void dump_with_types(ostream&,int) = 0; \ void dump_type(ostream&, int); \ Expression_class() { type = (Symbol) NULL; } #define Expression_SHARED_EXTRAS \ void dump_with_types(ostream&,int); … most certainly an “AHA” moment … and lots of scope for adding extra bits and pieces into the various classes … However … a helpful note in a structured code walkthrough would have saved much time ???

Instructor's Post
A couple of quick comments on this thread. First, the discussion of the visitor pattern is on target. That is what you will end up with in almost any reasonable implementation. The AST classes are set up to enable you to implement a visitor traversal of the AST by writing your own dynamically dispatched methods for, e.g., each of the different kinds of expressions. Second, there is a lot of other great material referenced in this thread (e.g., the Hindley-MIlner type system) which is well worth learning, but I don't really think is going to be particularly relevant to the programming assignment. There is a very wide variety of type systems out there and we only scratch the surface of the most commonly used design for object-oriented languages.

Title: Linking forum posts -compilers-01-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: Third programming assignment ...
Input.posts:
Conceptually building a semantic analyser for Cool - the goal of this programming assignment is not too difficult Actually implementing the code in a limited amount of time and with relatively little guidance is quite daunting ... especially on a distance learning course In the spirit of being helpful (hopefully) I'm going to post various links that might be of help (at least as it seems to me) ... In connection with type checking I came across something called the Hindley Milner type checking algorithm ... There are some MIT lecture slides on it ... - PhD Thesis (heavy going) http://gergo.erdi.hu/projects/tandoori/Tandoori-Compositional-Typeclass.pdf MIT Lecture Slides ... very helpful (at least for me) ... http://web.mit.edu/6.827/www/old/lectures/L07-Hindley-Milner2Print.pdf and http://web.mit.edu/6.827/www/old/lectures/L06-Hindley-MilnerPrint.pdf There is an implementation in C++ at https://github.com/jaredhoberock/hindley_milner This implementation makes use of Boost variants .. (a topic I am relatively new too .. but I see what the gist of it is ... ) Some references on Boost variants that might be of help http://boost.cowic.de/rc/pdf/variant.pdf http://blog.wuwon.id.au/2012/08/an-inline-variant-visitor-for-c.html In connection with semantic analysis in C++ there were quite a few references to using the Visitor pattern e.g. http://www.cs.colostate.edu/~cs453/yr2012/Slides/12-AST-visitor.ppt.pdf http://www.arl.wustl.edu/~mlw2/cse431/lec/visitor.pdf http://www.swe.uni-linz.ac.at/research/deco/designPatterns/visitor/visitor.abstract.html [ in connection with this web page .. the link to the iterator pattern is broken .... but the notes and comments are very relevant .. ] The visitor pattern approach is (IMHO) quite an elegant one ... I'll see how I get along with trying it out ... Notes re. iterator pattern mentioned above (snippet) Visiting across class hierarchies. An iterator can visit the objects in a structure as it traverses them by calling their operations. But an iterator can't work across object structures with different types of elements. For example, the following Iterator interface can access only objects of type Item : template class Iterator { // ... Item CurrentItem() const; }; This implies that all elements the iterator can visit have a common parent class Item . Visitor does not have this restriction. It can visit objects that don't have a common parent class. You can add any type of object to a Visitor interface. For example, in class Visitor { public: // ... void VisitMyType(MyType*); void VisitYourType(YourType*); }; MyType and YourType do not have to be related through inheritance at all. To my mind this is all pretty heavy going C++ coding .. and requires investing a lot of time in mastering quite a lot of more advanced C++ topics ... e.g Boost, templates, STL ... A small contribution, but still its a start (I hope) ... As I crawl along the stony path to possible enlightenment I'll try and contribute the various breadcrumbs that have served as markers on the way ... It would be nice if fellow pilgrims and strugglers could also add their breadcrumbs of partial enlightenment ...
